title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" and establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, amending the Internal Revenue Code to allow qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund and providing a special rule for assets held in the fund. Under this subsection, income, gain, loss, or deduction from assets in a natural disaster protection fund are not counted. Distributions from the fund are subject to specific rules, including excluding certain distributions from gross income if returned before filing taxes. Definitions and rules related to natural disasters are also provided. The new subsection in Section 832 of the Code defines a natural disaster protection fund as money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account. The fund must be designated as such and held in a regulated bank in the District of Columbia. The new subsection in Section 832 of the Code defines a natural disaster protection fund as money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account designated as such and held in a regulated bank in the District of Columbia. The fund must be invested in compliance with investment laws, and excess balance drawdowns must be distributed to the insurance company by the following taxable year. The new subsection in Section 832 of the Code defines a natural disaster protection fund as money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account in a regulated bank in the District of Columbia. An excess balance drawdown amount must be distributed to the qualified insurance company by the close of the following taxable year. A qualified insurance company is an insurer or reinsurer incorporated and domiciled in the District of Columbia, subject to supervision by the District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking, and maintains an office with a minimum number of employees. The District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking requires qualified insurance companies to have an office with a minimum number of employees, be subject to premium taxes, and additional taxes on natural catastrophic risk coverage written through the fund. The tax rate should not exceed the Federal excise tax rate. The District of Columbia sets the tax rate for qualified insurance companies, which should not exceed the Federal excise tax rate on reinsurance contracts. A qualified contribution is defined as a contribution to a fund established by a qualified insurance company, limited to the total of net premiums received for coverage of qualified losses. The qualified distribution from a fund established by a qualified insurance company should not exceed the amount at risk for qualified losses insured through the fund, as determined actuarially on a multi-year basis. Qualified distributions include payments for qualified losses, reinsurance, administrative expenses, excess balance drawdown, and claims investigation. The qualified distribution from a fund established by a qualified insurance company should not exceed the amount at risk for qualified losses insured through the fund. A qualified loss is an insured loss on a United States risk caused by events such as wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, or snow. The text chunk discusses various catastrophic events that can lead to insured losses exceeding $1,000,000,000 on an industry-wide basis or trigger a disaster declaration by the President of the United States. These events include floods, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, fires, hail, snow, ice, pandemics, or other public health catastrophes. The text chunk outlines conditions that can trigger a catastrophic industry-wide loss exceeding $1,000,000,000, including declarations by the President, Governor, or Property Claims Services unit. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the surplus fund balance at the end of the taxable year. The text chunk defines terms related to industry-wide losses, excess balance drawdown amount, United States risk, and exclusion of premiums and losses on certain Puerto Rican risks. The text chunk discusses the exclusion of premiums and losses on certain Puerto Rican risks, contributions in kind to a fund, and distributions in kind from a fund to a qualified insurance company. The text chunk discusses distributions of property other than money from a fund to a qualified insurance company, treating it as a sale or exchange with any gain or loss excluded from gross income. Additionally, it mentions regulations to be prescribed by the Secretary. The bill amends the tax code to impose a 20% tax on nonqualified distributions from a natural disaster protection fund made by qualified insurance companies. Definitions for nonqualified distributions, qualified insurance company, and natural disaster protection fund are provided. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
